Description: Red Deeps^^The place near Dorlcote Mill where Maggie Tulliver and Philip Wakem, her lover, meet. "Just where this line of bank sloped down again to the level, a by-road turned off and led to the other side of the rise, where it was broken into very capricious hollows and mounds by the working of an exhausted stone-quarry—so long exhausted that both mounds and hollows were now clothed with brambles and trees, and here and there by a stretch of grass which a few sheep kept close-nibbled." A little valley between Nuneaton and Griff House called Griff Bottoms or Griff Hollows was the original of the "Red Deeps".

Title: Pelley's Bank
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Pelley's Bank

Title: Park House
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Park House^^The home of the Guest family in St. Ogg's.

Title: Old Topping
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Old Topping^^Borough.

Title: Old Hall, St. Ogg's
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Old Hall, St. Ogg's^^The scene of the bazaar which is the culmination of Maggie Tulliver's social career. "It was the Normans who began to build that fine old hall, which is like the town telling of the thoughts and hands of widely-sundered generations; but it is all so old that we look with loving pardon at its inconsistencies, and are well content that they who built the stone oriel, and they who built the Gothic facade and towers of finest small brickwork with the refoil ornament, and the windows and battlements defined with stone, did not sacrilegiously pull down the ancient half-timbered body, with its oak - roofed banqueting-hall." "The fine old hall, with its open roof and carved oaken rafters, and great oaken foldingdoors, and light shed down from a height on the many-coloured show beneath: a very quaint place, with broad faded stripes painted on the walls, and here and there a show of heraldic animals of a bristly, long-snouted character, the cherished emblems of a noble family once the seigniors of this now civic hall. A grand arch, cut in the upper wall at one end, surmounted an oaken orchestra, with an open room behind it . . . Near the great arch over the orchestra was the stone oriel with painted glass, which was one of the venerable inconsistencies of the old hall." The original of the Old Hall, St. Ogg's, is the Old Hall, Gainsborough, the ancient residence of the lords of the manor of Gainsburgh, an interesting specimen of an old baronial hall. (For a history and description of this building, which is still standing, see Stark, History and Antiquities of Gainsburgh.)

Title: Mudport
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Mudport^^Town where Maggie Tulliver and Stephen Guest part after their flight.

Title: Luckreth
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Luckreth^^A village on the River Floss, which maggie and Stephen pass when they leave St. Ogg's together. It has been suggested that the original of Luckreth was Stockwith, a village on the Trent ("Floss "), about three and one-half miles north of Gainsborough ("St. Oggs "). (See article by John F. Fraser in the Bookman (London), vol. 9, p. 55.)

Title: Lindum
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Lindum^^Town near St. Ogg's. The original of Lindum was Lincoln.

Title: Laceham
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Laceham^^Town on the Floss, where Maggie Tulliver and her cousin Lucy are sent to boarding school, and where, later, Bob Jakin and Tom Tulliver get the lace goods with which they trade. The original of Laceham was Nottingham, noted for its lace manufacture.

Title: King's Lorton
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: King's Lorton^^The rural parish where Mr. Stelling is in charge when Tom Tulliver is sent to school to him.

Title: Kennel Yard, St. Ogg's
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Kennel Yard, St. Ogg's^^The place where one of Bob Jakin's friends who owns ferrets lives.

Title: Garum Firs
Subject: Fictional Place
Description:
Garum Firs^^The farm belonging to Mr. and Mrs. Pullet, where Tom and Maggie Tulliver and Lucy Deane visit, and where Maggie pushes Lucy into the pond. "All the farmyard life was wonderful there--bantams, speckled and top-knotted; Friesland hens, with their feathers all turned the wrong way; guinea-fowls that flew and screamed and dropped their pretty-spotted feathers; pouter-pigeons and a tame magpie; nay, a goat, and a wonderful brindled dog, half mastiff, half bull-dog, as large as a lion. Then there were white railings and white gates all about, and glittering weathercocks of various design, and garden-walks paved with pebbles in beautiful patterns —nothing was quite
common at Garum Firs: and Tom thought that the unusual size of the toads there was simply due to the general unusualness which characterized uncle Pullet's possessions as a gentleman farmer. Toads who paid rent were naturally leaner. As for the house, it was not less remarkable: it had a receding centre, and two wings with battlemented turrets, and was covered with glittering white stucco."

Title: Garum
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Garum^^The rich parish in which Mr. and Mrs. Pullet reside.

Title: Floss
Subject: Fictional Place
Description:
Floss^^River at St. Ogg's near which Mr. Tulliver's mill is situated. " A wide plain, where the broadening Floss hurries on
between its green banks to the sea, and the loving tide, rushing to meet it, checks its passage with an impetuous embrace. On this mighty tide the black ships--laden with the fresh-scented fir planks, with rounded sacks of oil-bearing seed, or with the dark glitter of coal-are borne along to the town of St. Ogg's, which shows its aged, fluted red roofs and the broad gables of its wharves between the low wooded hill and the river brink, tinging the water with a soft purple hue under the transient glance of this February sun... Just by the red-roofed town the tributary Ripple flows with a lively current into the Floss." As children Tom and Maggie Tulliver play along the Ripple and Floss, and later Maggie, Lucy Deane, and Stephen Guest go boatmg on it. The trading ships that carry Tom's venture
in Laceham goods sail down the Floss, and when Stephen Guest and Maggie go away together they are rowing on the river. When the great flood in September endangers the mill, Maggie rescues Tom in her rowboat, and it is in the swollen Floss that the two are drowned. The original of the Floss is the River Trent, on which the town of Gainsborough (the original of "St. Ogg's") is situated. The Trent is particularly liable to flooding in that region, and various destructive floods of the kind described in the catastrophe of "Mill on the Floss" have occurred in the neighbourhood of Gainsborough. The worst of these was the flood of 1770, referred to in the strory as having taken place 60 years before that in which Tom and Maggie perish.

Title: Firniss's (Miss) Boarding School
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Firniss's (Miss) Boarding School^^The school at Laceham which Maggie Tulliver and her cousin Lucy attend.

Title: Dunlow Common
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Dunlow Common^^The place where Maggie Tulliver hopes to find the gypsies when she runs away to them.

Title: Dorlcote Mill
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Dorlcote Mill^^The "Mill on the Floss". "And this is Dorlcote Mill . . . Even in this leafless time of departing February it is pleasant to look at—perhaps the chill damp season adds a charm to the trimly kept, comfortable dwelling-house, as old as the elms and chestnuts that shelter it from the northern blast. The stream is brimful now, and lies high in this little withy plantation, and half drowns the grassy fringe of the croft in front of the house." It had been the property of the Tullivers for five generations, but Mr. Tulliver loses it as a result of his many law-suits. When it then passes into the hands of Lawyer Wakem, his enemy, Mr. Tulliver continues as manager. When it is purchased by Guest & Co. some years after Mr. Tulliver's death, Tom Tulliver becomes its manager and it is from the Mill that Maggie rescues Tom in her row boat before both are drowned in the swollen Floss. A mill on the Trent (the "Floss") a short distance north of Gainsborough has been claimed as the original of Dorlcote Mill, but the description does not fit this, although it does fit, with considerable exactness, an old mill near George Eliot's childhood home at Griff. It is probably that she had this second mill in mind and moved it, in the novel, to the Trent, i.e. the "Floss". (See Olcott, George Eliot, pp. 76-7.) The description of some parts of the house, the attic, at least, was taken form George Eliot's childhood home, Griff House. (See Andrews, Bygone Warwickshire, p. 266).

Title: Danish Street
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Danish Street^^Street in St. Ogg's where Mr. Hyndmarsh has his grocery.

Title: Basset
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Basset^^Parish in which the Mosses live.

Title: "Shall I, Wasting in Despair" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: A song which Stephen Guest sings. The words were written by George Wither, 1617. The original setting, by a seventeenth century coposer is given in Chappell's Popular Music of the Olden Time.

Title: Purcell's Songs (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: Lucy Deane's favourites among the songs sung by Stephen Guest.

Title: "Masaniello, Duet In" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: Duet which Stephen Guest and Philip Wakem sing. "Masaniello" is the name given in England to D. F. E. Auber's opera "La mette de Portici".

Title: "Maid of Artois" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: Music which Stephen Guest brings to Lucy Dean. An opera by W. M. Balfe.

Title: "Love in Her Eyes Sits Playing" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: A song which Philip Wakem sings for Maggie Tulliver. A song from Handel's Acis and Galatea; the words are by John Gay.
Item Type Metadata:Text: Love in Her Eyes Sits Playing (Real)

Title: "Let Us Take The Road" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: A song from the "Beggar's Opera" sung by Lucy Deane, Philip Wakem, and Stephen Guest.

Title: "Hust, Ye Pretty Warbling Choir" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: One of the tunes played by Uncle Pullett's musical snuffbox. An air from Handel's masque or pastoral opera, "Acis and Galatea", composed about 1720. The words of the greater part, including this song, are by John Gay.

Title: "Graceful Consort" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: A song from "The Creation" which Lucy Deane and Stephen Guest sing. "Graceful consort at they side," a duet from "The Creation" by Haydn (1732-1809).

Title: "Creation" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: Lucy Deane and Stephen Guest sing several of the songs from the "Creation". An oratorio by Haydn (1732-1809).

Title: "Begone, Dull Care" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: A popular song, the words of which were suggested by a sixteenth century song, while the music was derived from the "Queen's Jig."

Title: York (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: York (Real)^^The town to which Maggie Tulliver goes after she leaves Stephen Guest. The ancient walled city of York, capital of Yorkshir, is about 42 miles northwest of Gainsborough (the "St. Ogg's" where Maggie Tulliver lived.)

Title: Scarborough (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Scarborough (Real)^^The place to which Lucy Deane goes with Stephen Guest's sisters. Scarborough is a popular coast resort in Yorkshire.

Title: Newcastle (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Newcastle (Real)^^Newcastle-upon-Tyne, the county town of Northumberland, situated about nine miles from the mouth of the Tyne.

Title: Guest & Co.
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: A prosperous firm in St. Ogg's, owning ships and mills, with a banking concern attached. Lucy Deane's father is a member of the firm, and Tom Tulliver is employed there after his father's failure.

Title: Grattan
Subject: Character Name
Description: A lad who shot his mother by accident, and who is befriended by Dr. Kenn.

Title: Gibson
Subject: Character Name
Description: A schoolmate of Tom Tulliver's.

Title: Garnett
Subject: Character Name
Description: An acquaintance of Mr. Tulliver's.

Title: Gadsby
Subject: Character Name
Description: One of Mr. Riley's acquaintances.

Title: Fibb's End
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Fibb's End

Title: Dix
Subject: Character Name
Description: A miller whose dispute with Mr. Tulliver about a dam is settled by arbitration.

Title: Beorl
Subject: Character Name
Description: The father of Ogg, the patron saint of St. Ogg's.

Title: Woodcock, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: An admirer of the Countess Czerlaski.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Tozer, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: An old gardener in Shepperton.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Tomms, Mr. Jacob
Subject: Character Name
Description: A young tailor of Shepperton.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Spratt, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: Master of the Shepperton Workhouse. In the lists of originals prepared in Nuneaton after the publication of the Scenes of Clerical Life, a Mr. Hackett was given as the original of Mr. Spratt. (See Olcott, George Eliot, p. 14.)
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Short, Mrs.
Subject: Character Name
Description: The landlady of Camp Villa. A Mrs. Fitchett is said to have been the original of Mrs. Short.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Radborough, Dean of
Subject: Character Name
Description: An acquaintance of the Countess Czerlaski's.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Pugh, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: The young curate of Whittlecombe who has "neat, black whiskers, and a pale complexion."
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Porter, Lady
Subject: Character Name
Description: The lady in whose family the Countess Czerlaski had been a governess.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Phipps, Mrs.
Subject: Character Name
Description: The wife of the Milby banker.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Phipps, Miss
Subject: Character Name
Description: The unattractive daughter of the Milby banker. Perhaps the same as the Miss Phipps in Janet's Repentance.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Parry, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: Amos Barton's predecessor at Shepperton; a popular preacher.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Organist, Shepperton
Subject: Character Name
Description: Original: Richard Stratton.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Landor, Mrs.
Subject: Character Name
Description: Wife of the Milby attorney.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Johns, Rev. Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: Of Gun Street Chapel. Possibly William Johns (1771-1845), a Unitarian minister, author and teacher. He taught in Manchester for thirty years.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Jackson, Miss
Subject: Character Name
Description: Mrs. Barton's maiden aunt, who had withdrawn herself and her income from the Barton home after a slight "tiff" with Amos.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Hackit, Mrs.
Subject: Character Name
Description: A sharp-tongued, very kind-hearted and benevolent woman with the courage of her opinions. "Mrs. Hackit declines cream; she has so long abstained from it with an eye to the weekly buttermoney, that abstinence, wedded to habit, has begotten aversion. She is a thin woman with a chronic liver-complaint, which would have secured her Mr. Pilgrim's entire regard and unreserved good word, even if he had not been in awe of her tongue, which was as sharp as his own lancet. She has brought her knitting—no frivolous fancy knitting, but a substantial woollen stocking; the click-click of her knitting-needles is the running accompaniment to all her conversation, and in her utmost enjoyment of spoiling a friend's self-satisfaction, she was never known to spoil a stocking." Although, in her blunt way, she tells Mr. Barton of her disapproval when he allows the Countess to quarter herself on him, she is a true friend to him and his family and a great help to him and Milly in their time of trouble. She is present at Milly's death. The original of Mrs. Hackit was Mrs. Robert Evans, George Eliot's mother. Mrs. Evans was an intimate friend of Mrs. Emma Gwyther ("Milly Barton") and the picture of Mrs. Hackit's relation to Milly Barton is true except in the detail of her being with Milly during Milly's last illness, as Mrs. Evans (" Mrs. Hackit ") died a few months before Mrs. Gwyther ("Milly"). (See Blind, George Eliot, p. 14; Cooke, George Eliot, p. 5, 281 ; Deakin, Early Life of George Eliot, p. 126.)
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Hackit, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: Churchwarden at Shepperton; a farmer, "a shrewd substantial man, whose advice about crops is always worth listening to, and who is too well-off to want to borrow money." Some suggestions for the character of Mr. Hackit were taken from the personality of George Eliot's father, Robert Evans (See Blind, George Eliot, p. 13; Deakin, Early Life of George Eliot, p.126).
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Gibbs, Miss Janet
Subject: Character Name
Description: Mrs. Patten's niece, "a single lady of fifty, hwo has refused the most ineligible offers out of devotion to her aged aunt." Nuneaton lists give her prototype variously as Miss Ibbetson, or Mrs. George Morris.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Furness, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: Curate; "a tall young man, with blond hair and whiskers." His prototype was the Rev. W. S. Bucknill, vicar of Burton-Hastings, near Nuneaton, 1844-73).
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Fudge, Poll
Subject: Character Name
Description: An insubordinate inmate of Shepperton workhouse. "Poll Fudge--known to the magistracy of her county as Mary Higgins--a one-eyed woman, with a scarred and seamy face, the mosts notorious rebel in the workhouse, said to have once thrown her broth over the master's coat-tails."
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Fudge, Master
Subject: Character Name
Description: Poll's small son, "most inveterate in ill-behavior during service time."
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Fitchett, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: An inmate of the Shepperton workhouse who had once been a footman in the Oldinport family. An old verger named Baker was said to have been the original of Mr. Fitchett (See Olcott, George Eliot, pp.15, 23.)
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Fellowes, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: Rector and magistrate, a man with a persuasive tongue. "A man of imposing appearance, with a mellifluous voice and the readiest of tongues. Mr. Fellowes once obtained a living by the persuasive charms of his conversation, and the fluency with which he interpreted the opinions of an obese and stammering baronet, so as to give that elderly gentleman a very pleasing perception of his own wisdom. Mr. Fellowes is a very successful man, and has the highest character everywhere except in his own parish, where, doubtless because his parishioners happen to be quarrelsome people, he is always at fierce feud with a farmer or two, a colliery proprietor, a grocer who was once churchwarden, and a tailor who formerly officiated as clerk." In the lists of originals made in Nuneaton after the publication of the Scenes of Clerical Life, the original of Mr. Fellowes was given as the Rev. Henry Bellairs (1790-1872), rector of Bedworth 1830-64.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Farquhar, Miss Julia
Subject: Character Name
Description: One of the squire's two daughters.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Farquhar, Miss Arabella
Subject: Character Name
Description: The squire's daughter, who sets her cap at Mr. Ely.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Farquhar, Mrs.
Subject: Character Name
Description: Mr. Farquhar's wife, one of Mrs. Barton's kind neighbours.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Farquhar, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: The secondary squire in Shepperton parish. The original of Mr. Farquhar was a Mr. Harper.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Ely, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: The agreeable bachelor clergyman of Milby. "Mr. Ely was a tall, darkhaired, distinguished-looking man of three-and-thirty. By the laity of Milby and its neighbourhood he was regarded as a man of quite remarkable powers and learning, who must make a considerable sensation in London pulpits and drawing rooms on his occasional visits to the metropolis; and by his brother clergy he was regarded as a discreet and agreeable fellow. Mr. Ely never got into a warm discussion; he suggested what might be thought, but rarely said what he thought himself ; he never let either men or women see that he was laughing at them, and he never gave anyone an opportunity of laughing at him. In one thing only be was injudicious. He parted his dark wavy hair down the middle; and as his head was rather flat than otherwise, that style of coiffure was not advantageous to him. The original of Mr. Ely was the Rev. William H. King, curate of Nuneaton.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Duke, Rev. Archibald
Subject: Character Name
Description: One of the clergymen present at the Clerical meeting at Milby Vicarage. "A very small man with a sallow and somewhat puffy face, whose hair is brushed straight up, evidently with the intention of giving him aheight somewhat less disproportionate to his sense of his own importance than the measure of five feet three accorded him by an oversight of nature. This is the Rev. Archibald Duke, a very dyspeptic and evangelical man, who takes the gloomiest view of mankind and their prospects, and thinks the immense sale of the Pickwick Papers, recently completed, one of the strongest proofs of original sin. Unfortunately, though Mr. Duke was not burdened with a family, his yearly expenditure was apt considerably to exceed his income; and the unpleasant circumstances resulting from this, together with heavy meat breakfasts, may probably have contributed to his desponding views of the world generally." In the lists of originals made in Nuneaton after the publication of Scenes of Clerical Life, the original of the Reverend Archibald Duke was the Reverend Mr. Hoke. (See Olcott, George Eliot, p. 14.)
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Czerlaski, Caroline, Countess
Subject: Character Name
Description: A pretty, selfish widow with small means, anxious to find a second husband with money. "The Countess Czerlaski was undeniably beautiful… small hands and feet, a tall lithe figure, large dark eyes, and dark silken braided hair. All these the Countess possessed, and she had, morever, a delicately formed nose, the least bit curved, and a clear brunette complexion. Her mouth, it must be admitted, receded too much from  her nose and chin, and to prophetic eye threatened 'nut-crackers' in advanced age. But by the light of fire and wax candles that age seemed very far off indeed, and you would have said that the Countess was not more than thirty." After settling near Shepperton with her brother, Mr. Bridmain, she cultivates the acquaintance of the Bartons. When her brother marries her maid she quarters herself on the Bartons for many months, thus heavily taxing their small means, arousing gossip and bringing down on Mr. Barton's head the wrath of his parish. The prototype of the Countess Czerlaski was the "Countess Isabel". (Manuscript information; also Olcott, George Eliot, p. 15.)
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Czerlaski, Count
Subject: Character Name
Description: A foreign nobleman with small fortune who had earned his living by giving dancing lessons.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Cramp, Mrs.
Subject: Character Name
Description: Charwoman who helps at Shepperton Vicarage.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Cleves, Rev. Martin
Subject: Character Name
Description: Rector of Tripplegate, Amos Barton's neighbour and kind friend. "A man about forty, middle-sized, broad-shouldered, with a negligently-tied cravat, large irregular features, and a large head, thickly covered with lanky brown hair… there is the true pariah preist, the pastor beloved, consulted, relied on by his flock; a clergyman who is not associated with the undertaker, but thought of as the surest helper under a difficulty, as a monitor who is encouraging rather than sever. Mr. Cleves has the wonderful art of preaching sermons which the wheelwright and the blacksmith can understand, not because he talks condescending twaddle, but because he can call a spade a spade, and knows how to disencumber words of their wordy frippery." In lists of originals which were made in Nuneaton after the publication of Scenes of Clerical Life, the prototype of the Reverend Mr. Cleves was given as the Reverend John Fisher. (See Olcott, George Eliot, p.14.)
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Carpe, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: The non-resident Vicar of Shepperton, who comes to reside at Shepperton as a pretext for removing Amos Barton, in order ultimately to give the curacy to his own brother-in-law.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Bridmain, Mr. Edmund
Subject: Character Name
Description: Countess Czerlaski's half-brother, a retired silk manufacturer, who marries his sister's maid. "Mr. Bridmain… by unimpeached integrity and industry, had won a partnership in a silk manufactory, and thereby a moderate fortune, that enabled him to retire... to study politics, the weather, and the art of conversation, at his leisure... Every man who is not a monster, a mathematician, or a mad philosopher, is the slave of some woman or other. Mr. Bridmain had put his neck under the yoke of his handsome sister, and though his soul was a very little one--of the smallest description indeed--he would not have ventured to call it his own." In the lists of originals which were made in Nuneaton after the publication of Scenes of Clerical Life the original of Mr. Bridmain was said to be Sir John Waldron.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Brick, Mrs.
Subject: Character Name
Description: An inmate of Shepperton workhouse, an old woman much given to snuff. " Mrs. Brick, one of those hard undying old women, to whom age seems to have given a network of wrinkles, as a coat of magic armour against the attacks of winters, warm or cold. The point on which Mrs. Brick was still sensitive - the theme on which you might possibly excite her hope and fear - was snuff . It seemed to be an embalming powder, helping her soul to do the office of salt."
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Blarney, Lord
Subject: Character Name
Description: An acquaintance mentioned by the Countess Czerlaski.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Blacksmith, Popish
Subject: Character Name
Description: Original: Bull, of Griff.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Barton, Walter
Subject: Character Name
Description: Milly's year-old baby.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Barton, Sophy
Subject: Character Name
Description: One of the Barton children.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Barton, Patty
Subject: Character Name
Description: The Barton's eldest child; a sweet, serious girl who takes her mother's place after Milly's death, and remains her father's devoted companion.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Barton, Fred
Subject: Character Name
Description: The Barton's eldest son.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Barton, Dickey
Subject: Character Name
Description: The Barton's second boy, an affectionate little fellow, "a boisterous boy of five, with large pink cheeks and sturdy legs;" in later life a talented engineer. He is Mrs. Hackit's favorite.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Barton, Chubby
Subject: Character Name
Description: The Barton's youngest girl.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Barton, Rev. Amos
Subject: Character Name
Description: Curate of Shepperton; a commonplace man with a large family and insufficient means. In his mediocre way he tries to attend to all parish duties, but with a small stipend can never make both ends meet, and has to be helped by his parishioners and his squire. Dazzled by the Countess Czerlaski's pretended gentility, he receives her into his family when she quarrels with her brother, and thus increases the existing gossip and alienates his parishioners. He regains their regard only when crushed under the grief of Milly's death. The original of Amos Barton was the Rev. John Gwyther, B.A., curate of Chilvers Coton during George Eliot's girlhood and, later, vicar of Fewston, York shire, where he died in 1873.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Barton, Mrs. Amelia, called Milly
Subject: Character Name
Description:
Amos Barton's beautiful and loveable wife, the mother of a large family of children. She is loved by all her husband's
parishioners, who for her sake modify their criticism of the less popular Amos. With entirely inadequate means she cheerfully and skilfully contrives to meet the needs of her large family, and her whole life is given in loving service to Amos and her children. Entirely honest and guileless herself, she does not see through the shallow pretence of the Countess Czerlaski, and when the Countess quarters herself on the Barton household Milly loads herself with extra burdens to make the visitor comfortable. The strain proves too much, and after the birth of her seventh child she dies, thinking to the last of the welfare of her children and husband. The original of Milly Barton was Mrs. Emma
Gwyther, nee Wilson, wife of the Reverend John Gwyther. They had six children. Mrs. Evans, George Eliot's mother (the original of Mrs. Hackit), was her intimate friend, but was not with her in her last illness, as Mrs. Evans died shortly before Mrs. Gwyther. The name Milly Barton was probably suggested by that of " Mrs. Milly Barton ", a sister of Lady Newdigate, second wife of Sir Roger Newdigate.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Baird, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: A young clergyman present at the clerical meeting held at Milby Vicarage. In the lists of originals which were made in Nuneaton after the publication of Scenes of Clerical Life the original of Mr. Baird was said to be the Rev. George William Sanford, Vicar of Weddington.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Subject: Character Name
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Subject: Character Name
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Subject: Character Name

Title: "The Jolly Colliers"
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: "The Jolly Colliers"^^Inn at Shepperton.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: "Gun Street Chapel"
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: "Gun Street Chapel"^^An independent chapel. This may be a reference to some real chapel in Gun Street, Manchester, though no such building is there now. In the original manuscript of the story the chapel is called "Bullock Lane Chapel".
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: "College"
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: "College"^^Name given to Shepperton workhouse, "a huge square stone building," where Amos Barton reads prayers. The original of the "College" was the Chilvers Coton workhouse or "College for the Poor, 1800", as it was inscribed.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Simeon, Mr. (Hist.)
Subject: Historical Name
Description: Charles Simeon (1759-1836), an evangelical clergyman, holder of the living of Trinity Church, Cambridge.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: "Silly Jim"
Subject: Item
Description: An inmate of the Shepperton workhouse, affected with hydrocephalus.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: "Old Maxum"
Subject: Item
Description: A pauper patriarch of ninety-five, stone deaf.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Sargent
Subject: Character Name
Description: Clergyman.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Rachel
Subject: Character Name
Description: Mrs. Hackit's housemaid.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Prior
Subject: Character Name
Description: A deceased clergyman with whom Amos Barton had been friendly.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Nanny
Subject: Character Name
Description: The Barton's devoted maid-of-all-work, "who had a warm heart and still warmer temper."
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Jet
Subject: Character Name
Description: The Countess Czerlaski's spaniel.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Witherington
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Witherington^^Place where Mr. Sargent used to be curate.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Whittlecombe
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Whittlecombe^^Parish near Shepperton, of which Mr. Pugh is curate. In the lists of originals prepared at Nuneaton after the publication of Scenes of Clerical Life, the original of Whittlecombe was given as Stockingford. (See Olcott, George Eliot, p. 15.)
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Tripplegate
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Tripplegate^^Mr. Cleves' parish. In the lists of originals prepared in Nuneaton after the publication of the Scenes of Clerical Life, Higham is given as the original of Tripplegate. (See Olcott, George Eliot, p. 15.)
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Tetterley
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Tetterley^^Place where Lord Watling's farm is located.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Shepperton Church
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Shepperton Church^^Amos Barton's church. "Shepperton Church was a very different-looking building five-andtwenty years ago. To be sure, its substantial stone tower looks at you through its intelligent eye, the clock, with the friendly expression of former days; but in everything else what changes! . . . I recall with a fond sadness Shepperton Church as it was in the old days, with its outer coat of rough stucco, its red-tiled roof, its heterogeneous windows patched with desultory bits of painted glass, and its little flight of steps with their wooden rail running up the outer wall, and leading to the schoolchildren's gallery." The well-known original of Shepperton Church is the Church at Chilvers Coton, where George Eliot was baptised and which she attended as a child. (See Cross, George Eliot's Life, vol. 1, p. 2.)
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Dippley
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Dippley^^Place belonging to the Porters.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Cross Farm
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Cross Farm^^Mrs. Patten's farm at Shepperton.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Camp Villa
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Camp Villa^^Residence of the Countess Czerlaski and her brother, situated half a mile from Milby. The original of Camp Villa was a house near Nuneaton called the Briars.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Brand, Mr.
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Brand, Mr.^^The Shepperton doctor, "obnoxious to Mr. Pilgrim." In the lists of originals which were made in Nuneaton after the publications of the Scenes of Clerical Life, the original of Mr. Brand was said to be a Mr. Harris.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: "Wedding Psalm" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: The psalm which caused a row when sung in Shepperton Church. W. Whittingham's version of the 133rd Psalm, in the old version of the Psalter.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: "Tempest, The" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: The music of "The Tempest" is among the songs sung by Stephen Guest, Philip Wakem, and Lucy Deane. The incidental music of The Tempest was written by Thomas A. Arne (1710-78), when the play was revived at Drury Lane Theatre, 1746.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: "Record" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: A periodical which Amos Barton would have taken in if he had been able to afford it. The Record, first published 1828, represented the views of the Evangelical element of the Church of England.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: "Lydia" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: A tune which Mr. Barton sets in church, thereby scandalizing Mr. Farquhar. Composed by Thomas Phillipe (1774-1841), and used in Nonconformist hymnbooks before it was adopted in the Church of England.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Christian Observer (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: A periodical which Amos Barton would have taken in if he had been able to afford it. A monthly magazine, published 1802-74; continued as the Christian Observer and Advocate, 1875-1877.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Dolby
Subject: Character Name
Description: Architect.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Coppleton Church
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Coppleton Church
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Bramhill
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: A living of Lord Watling's.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Betty
Subject: Character Name
Description: Mrs. Patten's dairymaid.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Bagshawe
Subject: Character Name
Description: A clergyman.
Source: The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton

Title: Such, Reverend Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: Theophrastus Such's father, a country clergy man in the Midlands. "My father was none the less beloved because he was under stood to be of asaving disposition. . . . The sight of him was not un welcome at any door, and he was remarkable among the clergy of his district for having no lasting feud with rich or poor in his parish . . . He was apithy talker, and his sermons bore marks of his own composition.

Title: Silva, Duke
Subject: Character Name
Description: "Born de la Cerda, Calatravan Knight, Count of Segura, Fourth Duke of Bedmar." The Spanish Commander of Bedmar, who is betrothed to Fedalma, the Spanish Gypsy. "On his surcoat white / Glitter the sword-belt and the jewelled hilt, / Red on the back and breast the holy cross, / And 'twixt the helmet and the soft-spun white / Thick tawny wavelets like the lion's mane / Turn backward from his brow pale, wide, erect, / Shadowing blue eyes-blue as the rain-washed sky / That braced the early stem of Gothic kings / He claims for ancestry. A goodly knight / A noble caballero, broad of chest / And long of limb." He is in command of the fortress of Bedmar, an outpost in Andalusia, but is not, so rumour goes, pressing his command against the Moors very vigorously because he is loath to leave his betrothed, Fedalma, a beautiful Gypsy girl who had been adopted by his mother, the Duchess Diana. Knowing that Fedalma is menaced by the Inquisition, he presses for an immediate marriage. When Fedalma, on learning that Zarca, the captured Gypsy chief, is her long-lost father casts in her lot with him and escapes with him from Bedmar, Duke Silva is broken-hearted. He follows Fedalma to the Gypsy camp, and when he cannot persuade her to return, elects to remain with her and become a Gypsy. Mean while the Moors and Gypsies attack Bedmar, and Silva brought back there finds his trust betrayed, his friends slain and his uncle, Father Isidor, the Inquisitor, about to be executed. Unable to prevail upon Zarca to spare the Prior's life, Silva kills Zarca, by that act separating himself forever from Fedalma.

Title: Sephardo, Salomo
Subject: Character Name
Description: A Jewish sage; the astrologer of Abderahmen's tower, whose aid and counsel Duke Silva seeks after Fedalma's departure.

Title: Marcos, Father
Subject: Character Name
Description: A priest who says Fedalma is an infidel.

Title: Lorenzo, formerly called Ephraim
Subject: Character Name
Description: Innkeeper at Bedmar; the son of a converted Jew.

Title: Lopez, Captain
Subject: Character Name
Description: A Spanish captain, in charge of the guard of the Gypsy prisoners.

Title: Isidor, Father
Subject: Character Name
Description: Duke Silva's uncle, a Prior of San Domingo and an Inquisitor; "a holy, high-born, stern Dominican." He is bitterly opposed to Duke Silva's proposed marriage to Fedalma, on the ground that she is of alien race and a heretic. Finding it impossible to dissuade the Duke, he is on the point of having her seized by the Inquisition, but she escapes him by going off with her father, Zarca. When Zarca and the Moors take Bedmar, the Prior is captured; Zarca saves him from immediate death by burning at the hands of the mob, and has him hanged instead. Before his death he sees Duke Silva in Gypsy dress and curses him as a traitor.

Title: Diego, Don
Subject: Character Name
Description: A fiery don, Duke Silva's lieutenant to whom the Duke transfers the command when he is ill. "Don Diego, a most valiant man / More Catholic than the Holy Father's self / Half chiding God that he will tolerate / A Jew or Arab; though 'tis plain they're made / For profit of."

Title: Diana, Duchess
Subject: Character Name
Description: Duke Silva's dead mother.

Title: Roldan
Subject: Character Name
Description: The juggler, a disappointed middle-aged man, on whom life has been hard. He performs in the Placa Santiago, and later is sent as a messenger by Duke Silva to obtain news of Fedalma in the Gypsy camp.

Title: Pedro
Subject: Character Name
Description: Servant at Lorenzo's inn.

Title: Pablo
Subject: Character Name
Description: The lame son of Roldan, the juggler; a mournful twelve-year-old boy, with a beautiful voice. "He sings G0d-taught such / marrow-thrilling strains / As seem the very voice of dying Spring, / A flute-like wail that mourns the blossoms gone."

Title: Market-Woman
Subject: Character Name
Description: The messenger who delivers to Lorenzo, concealed in an apple, a letter from the Gypsy chief, Zarca, to the Moor, El Zagal.

Title: Juan
Subject: Character Name
Description: Poet and minstrel; a friend both to Duke Silva and to the Spanish Gypsy, Fedalma, with whom he is unselfishly in love. "So Juan was a troubadour revived / Freshening life's dusty road with babbling rills / Of wit and song, living mid harnessed men / With limbs ungalled by armour." Juan forms a connecting link in several parts of the plot. His light talk with the Gypsy prisoner, Zarca, enables the Gypsy to recognize Fedalma as his lost daughter. When Fedalma throws in her lot with her father and the Gypsies escape from Bedmar, Juan goes with them to the Gypsy camp at Guadix, and is there when Duke Silva, for love of Fedalma, joins the Gypsies. When Fedalma after her father's death is embarking for Africa it is Juan who sees the pilgrim Silva on the strand, and urges Fedalma to a last interview with the lover from whom she is separated for ever.

Title: Jose
Subject: Character Name
Description: A young gentleman of Duke Silva's household.

Title: Ismael
Subject: Character Name
Description: Gypsy boy, in love with Hinda.

Title: Inez
Subject: Character Name
Description: Fedalma's old trusted nurse.

Title: Hurtado
Subject: Character Name
Description: A young gentleman of Duke Silva's household.

Title: Fedalma
Subject: Character Name
Description:
Zarca's daughter, betrothed to Duke Silva; a beautiful, gifted, high-minded Gypsy, who finds herself called upon to make a great renunciation for the sake of her people. St.olen from her people when a mere infant, she had been taken into the family of the Duchess Diana and brought up there with all love and tenderness. She and the young Duke Silva are betrothed, and when their mamage is near, Fedalma, deeply in love and looking forward to a happy future, learns from the prisoner Zarca that he is her father. When Zarca, a patriot and a visionary, points out to her the needs of her people and all that she can do for them if she will cast in her lot with them, she at first tries to reconcile love and duty, but later makes the sacrifice of her personal happiness, gives up Silva, and joins her father in his escape. When Silva, desperate at her loss, follows her and joins the Gypsy band to win her, she cannot rejoice entirely, as she feels that he is defying inherited obligations which will later become insistent. After Zarca captures
Silva's town of Bedmar, and Silva, desperate with shame, kills Zarca, Fedalma finds herself separated for ever from her lover. She has one farewell interview with Silva, and then, renouncing all thought of self, leads her people to Africa.

Title: Zagal, El (Hist.)
Subject: Historical Name
Description: The Moorish king, with whom Zarca and his Gypsies are allied fro the taking of Bedmar. Abdullah el Zagal, Moslem king of Granada, 1484-9.

Title: Zind
Subject: Character Name
Description: Fedalma's Gypsy nurse, who lost her when she was a baby.

Title: Zincali
Subject: Character Name
Description: The Spanish Gypsies, Zarca's men.

Title: Zarca
Subject: Character Name
Description: A Gypsy chief, Fedalma's father. A man of lofty and resolute purpose, capable of putting the claims of his people ahead of all personal considerations, he aspires to fuse together the scattered bands of Gypsies in Spain and lead them to found a Gypsy nation in Africa. At the opening of the poem he is held prisoner by the Spaniards in Bedmar, where he sees the beautiful Fedalm.a, the Duke's betrothed, and recognizes her as his long lost daughter, who had been stolen in childhood by marauding Spaniards. Revealing himself to her, he sets before her the claims of her race and so works upon her with his force and eloquence that she agrees to leave Duke Silva, whom she loves devotedly, and to escape with her father and devote herself to the welfare of her race. After Duke Silva, unable to bear the loss of Fedalma, follows her to the Gypsy camp and for her sake joins the Gypsy band, deserting his post at Bedmar, Zarca, and his Moorish ally, El Zagal, attack and capture Bedmar. Zarca shows some moderation in his victory, although he condemns the inquisitor, Father Isidor, to death, and when Silva, frantic at Father Isidor's death and the thought that the loss of the town is due to his desertion of his post, stabs Zarca, the Gypsy protects him and will not allow his people to harm Silva. Dying, Zarca lays upon Fedalma the solemn duty of taking his place in the leadership of his people. Frederic Harrison has suggested that some traits in the character of Zarca were drawn from Dr. Richard Congreve, the Positivist leader. (See article in the Positivist Review, vol. 10, p. 160.) Congreve himself once declared that the Spanish Gypsy was a "mass of Positivism".

Title: Tralla
Subject: Character Name
Description: A gypsy girl.

Title: Seneca
Subject: Pet Name
Description: The Host's dog, a solemn mastiff.

Title: Saad
Subject: Pet Name
Description: Hita's dog.

Title: Ramon
Subject: Character Name
Description: An old trumpeter in Duke Silva's train, who "takes his trumpeting as solemnly as angel charged to wake the dead".

Title: Pepita
Subject: Character Name
Description: A Spanish girl who watches the juggling in the Placa Santiago; she is in love with Juan the Minstrel.

Title: Pepe
Subject: Character Name
Description: The small son of Lorenzo, the innkeeper.

Title: Nouna
Subject: Character Name
Description: A Gypsy.

Title: Nadar
Subject: Character Name
Description: A Gypsy captain.

Title: Lola
Subject: Character Name
Description: A heavy Spanish girl at the Inn.

Title: Lambra
Subject: Character Name
Description: Fedalma's dead mother.

Title: Bedmar
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Bedmar^^Town in Spain, the principal scene of the Spanish Gypsy. There is a small town of Bedmar in the province of Jaen, in Andalusia, Spain, which has a ruined fortress, dating from Moorish times, with the remains of a secret passage somewhat like the one described in the poem.

Title: Hita
Subject: Character Name
Description: A Gypsy girl, one of the three that tease Juan the minstrel.

Title: Hinda
Subject: Character Name
Description: Prettiest and boldest of the three Gypsy girls that tease Juan, the minstrel.

Title: Hassan
Subject: Character Name
Description: A Gypsy, Zarca's lieutenant.

Title: Fabian
Subject: Character Name
Description: A member of Duke Silva's retinue.

Title: Enriquez
Subject: Character Name
Description: A member of Duke Silva's retinue.

Title: Blasco
Subject: Character Name
Description: A prosperous silversmith in Aragon.

Title: Bavieca
Subject: Pet Name
Description: Duke Silva's black charger.

Title: Laertes
Subject: Character Name
Description: A guest at the college breakfast party.

Title: Butterworth, Elias Baptist
Subject: Character Name
Description: A vegetarian, who believes that a millenium will come when flesh-eating ceases. He and his beliefs furnish a text for the poem.

Title: Michael, Master
Subject: Character Name
Description: Innkeeper.

Title: Linda, Countess
Subject: Character Name
Description: The fair, gentle young court lady to whome the saintly peasant Agatha talkes of her simple faith.

Title: Limp, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: "A meditative shoe-maker, with weak eyes and a piping voice."

Title: Nell
Subject: Character Name
Description: One of Agatha's old cousins.

Title: Kate
Subject: Character Name
Description: One of Agatha's old cousins.

Title: Dornberg, Graf
Subject: Character Name
Description: A noble in love with Armgart, who asks her to marry him and give up her career when she is at the height of her success, but does not renew his offer after her voice fails her.

Title: Walpurga, Fraulein
Subject: Character Name
Description: Armgart's humble and self-effacing cousin, who serves Armgart with uncomplaining affection in the days of her brilliant success, and after Armgart loses her voice rouses her from her despair by showing her the claims of others.

Title: Grahn, Doctor
Subject: Character Name
Description: Armgart's physician, who cures the singer of her sharp illness, but does not save her voice.

Title: Leo
Subject: Character Name
Description: Armgart's devoted old music master, who, when his own music is forgotten, trains her voice to perfection. After she loses her voice, his story and example encourage her to "bury her dead joy" and live for others.

Title: Gretchen
Subject: Character Name
Description: Armgart's maid.

Title: Sister
Subject: Character Name
Description: The younger of the two children in the poem Brother and Sister. The little sister adores her brother, who is the hero and leader in their childish rambles near their country home, and finds her greatest happiness in being with him and pleasing him. Grown up and separated from him in later life, she can still exclaim:—"But were another childhoodworld my share, / I would be born a little sister there." The poem Brother and Sister is autobiographic and describes the relation between George Eliot, the "Sister" of the poem, and her brother, Isaac Evans.

Title: Brother
Subject: Character Name
Description: The elder of the two children in the poem Brother and Sister. He is the hero and leader in the childish adventures and explorations, and is followed with puppy-like affection by his little sister of four or five years of age. The poem Brother and Sister is autobiographic, and describes the relation between George Eliot and her brother Isaac Evans, the "Brother" of the poem.

Title: Character Name
Subject: Character Name
Description: Character Name
Dublin Core:Creator: Character Name

Title: Genoa (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Genoa (Real)^^City in Italy, where Daniel Deronda meets his mother, and where Mr. and Mrs. Grandcourt are staying when Grandcourt is drowned. In Romola, Baldassarre Calvo is taken to Genoa, when a Genoese merchant rescues him from slavery at Corinth, and in Genoa he sees the man who has bought Tito Melema's onyx ring.

Title: Crowe, Widow
Subject: Character Name
Description: Macarthy's land-lady.

Title: Macarthy
Subject: Character Name
Description: A recluse who dies young leaving behind him many manuscripts.

Title: Idione
Subject: Character Name
Description: The hamadryad who was sad because she grew old.

Title: Hieria
Subject: Character Name
Description: The hamadryad who never knew that she grew old.

Title: Minuccio
Subject: Character Name
Description: The great singer, who reveals to King Pedro, by means of his song, the touching story of gentle Lisa's love. " . . . A singer of the most gentle fame, / A noble, kindly spirit, not elate / That he was famous, but that song was great."

Title: Lisa
Subject: Character Name
Description: A fair young girl of Palermo who falls deeply and innocently in love with King Pedro, when she sees him at a tournament. Wasting away with her hopeless love, and grieving over the thought of dying while the king is still ignorant of her feeling for him, she confides her story to Minuccio, the sweet singer, and bids him sing it to the king. Touched by Minuccio's song, the king visits Lisa and bids her live, and he and his Queen take Lisa and Perdicone, whom she marries happily, under their protection. Thereafter the King always calls himself Lisa's faithful knight. The poem "How Lisa loved the King " is a poetical version of one of Boccaccio's tales. The original story is given in the Decamerone, tenth day, novel seven.

Title: Pedro, King of Aragon (Hist.)
Subject: Historical Name
Description: The gallant ruler of Sicily with whom young Lisa falls in love when she sees him at a tourna ment. When he learns from the minstrel Minuccio that the maiden is dying for love of him, he visits her and bids her live and he and his queen, Constance, take Lisa and her suitor, Perdicone, under their protection and advance their fortunes. Thereafter King Pedro wears Lisa's favour, and calls himself her faithful knight. George Eliot's poem tells the story of Lisa and King Pedro, without change of plot, from the tale in Boccaccio's Decamerone, tenth day, novel seven. The king in the story is Pedro III, King of Aragon, who acquired his claims in Sicily through his queen, Constance, daughter of Manfred of Beneventum, King of Sicily. Pedro became King of Aragon in 1276, King of Sicily in 1282, and died 1285.

Title: Constance, Queen (Hist.)
Subject: Historical Name
Description: King Pedro's gentle queen, who is touched by Lisa's story and takes her under her protection. Constance, daughter of Manfred of Beneventum, wife of Pedro III of Aragon; it was through her that Pedro acquired his rights over Sicily.

Title: Perdicone
Subject: Character Name
Description: Lisa's suitor, whom she marries later.

Title: Mico
Subject: Character Name
Description: Minuccio's poet friend.

Title: Palermo (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Palermo (Real)^^Scene of the poem "How Lisa loved the King." —Palermo, the capital and largest city of Sicily, on the north coast of the island. At the time of Lisa Sicily was ruled by King Pedro III, of Aragon, and his queen, Constance (daughter of Manfred of Beneventum), through whom Pedro had acquired his Sicilian rights.

Title: Bernardo
Subject: Character Name
Description: A rich Florentine; Lisa's father.

Title: "Orpheus" (Real)
Subject: Real Name
Description: An opera by Gluck, in the title role of which Armgart scores her great success. "Orpheus and Euridice," or "Orfeo ed Euridice", by Christoph Wilibald Gluck, first performed 1762. The song "Che faro senza Euridice", which Caterina Sarti sings, in Mr. Gilfil's Love Story, is from this opera, and in the first edition of Mr. Gilfil, both "Che faro" and Caterina's other song,  "Ho perduto il bel sembiante" were mentioned as being in the "Orpheus". In the revised edition, however, George Eliot omitted in chapter ii, the name of the opera and changed the text to read "Sir Christopher's favourite airs, by Gluck and Paisiello".

Title: Southampton (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Southampton (Real)^^An English seaport on the Channel; a principal port for transatlantic steamers.
Source: Multiple (Daniel Deronda, Felix Holt, the Radical)

Title: Christ's Hospital (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Christ's Hospital (Real)^^School from which Hans Meyrick enters Cambridge as an exhibitioner. In Felix Holt, Mr. Jermyn "had got his Latin there for nothing". Christ's Hospital, the famous "Blue Coat School" founded by Edward VI, was in London at the period of Daniel Deronda. It has since been moved to the country.
Source: Multiple (Daniel Deronda, Felix Holt, the Radical)

Title: Eton (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Eton (Real)^^The public school where Daniel Deronda was educated befroe he went to Cambridge. In Felix Holt, Harold Transome had been educated at Eton and in the Lifted Veil Latimer's elder brother had been at that school. Eton College, at Eton, near Windsor, founded in 1440 by Henry VI.
Source: Multiple (Felix Holt, the Radical, Daniel Deronda, The Lifted Veil)

Title: Davy, Sir Humphry (Hist.)
Subject: Historical Name
Description: A chemist and poet with whom Mr. Brooke had once dined. Sir Humphry Davy (1778-1829) chemist and author.

Title: Constantinople (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Constantinople (Real)^^In Felix Holt Harold Transome goes to Constantinople as an attache of the British Embassy; in Romola Constantinople is one of the places where Tito Melema had lived. Constantinople, the capital of the Eastern Empire, was captured by the Turks in 1453, and after that date many Greek scholars made their way from there to Italy.

Title: Milby
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Milby^^Market town; scene of the story of Janet's Repentance, and of some of the action in the other Scenes of Clerical Life. "It was a dingy-looking town, with a strong smell of tanning up one street and a great shaking of hand-looms up another . . . To a superficial glance, Milby was nothing but dreary prose: a dingy town, surrounded by flat fields, lopped elms, and sprawling manufacturing villages, which crept on and on with their weaving-shops, till they threatened to graft themselves on the town." The easily recognized original of Milby is the market and manufacturing town of Nuneaton, Warwickshire. The name was taken from an old corn-mill in Nuneaton, on the Anker, called Milby Mill. (See Dryden, Memorials of Old Warwickshire, p. 124 ; Parkinson, Scenes, pp. 12, 55-8.)
Source: Multiple (Janet's Repentance, The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton, Mr. Gilfil's Love Story)

Title: Landor, Mr. Benjamin
Subject: Character Name
Description: Lawyer, the banker's son.
Source: Multiple (Janet's Repentance, The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton)

Title: Milby Vicarage
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Mibly Vicarage^^Scene of the Clerical Meeting, where Amos Barton's shortcomings are discussed. This is the Vicarage in Nuneaton, near the Church.
Source: Multiple (Janet's Repentance, The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton)

Title: Liverpool (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Liverpool (Real)^^In Adam Bede Arthur Donnithorne lands at Liverpool on his return from Ireland; in Brother Jacob David Faux sails from Liverpool to seek his fortune in America.
Source: Multiple (Middlemarch, Adam Bede, Brother Jacob, Janet's Repentance)

Title: London (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: London (Real)^^London is the main scene in Daniel Deronda, through the residence there of the Cohens and the Meyricks, etc., and it is mentioned, as a very minor scene, in several of the stories of provincial life. Various localities and buildings in London and its vicinity are mentioned in the different novels. All of these which have any part, however small, in the plots of the stories, are entered separately in their alphabetical places in the Dictionary, and the fuller in formation, including the historical notes, is given under these separate entries. The following list will show at a glance what localities in London and its immediate vicinity are mentioned.
Source: Multiple (Middlemarch, Adam Bede, Daniel Deronda, The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton, Felix Holt, the Radical, Janet's Repentance, The Mill on the Floss)

Title: Rome (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Rome (Real)^^In Middlemarch Rome is the city to which Mr. and Mrs. Casaubon go on their wedding journey. In Romola Tito Melema twice goes there on political errands, and it is the centre of the agitation against Savonarola, under the Pope's leadership. Under Alexander the Sixth (1492-1503), who was Pope during the period of Romola, the will of the Pope was absolute in Rome, and the Papal states of which he was the head were one of the five great powers of Italy.

Title: Paris (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Paris (Real)^^In Middlemarch Paris is one of the places where Dr. Lydgate had studied medicine.
Source: Multiple (Middlemarch, Daniel Deronda, The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton)

Title: Loamford
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Loamford^^Town where Felix Holt is imprisoned and tried. In Middlemarch Loamford is a town in the vicinity of Middlemarch.
Source: Multiple (Middlemarch, Felix Holt, the Radical, Adam Bede)

Title: Huskisson (Hist.)
Subject: Historical Name
Description: A statesman who is killed by the new railrod. William Huskisson (1770-1830), who was killed at the opening of the Liverpool and Manchester Railroad, 15th September, 1830.

Title: "Gentleman's Magazine"
Subject: Item
Description: The Gentleman's Magazine, London, founded 1731.

Title: Naples (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Naples (Real)^^The Naples which figures in Daniel Deronda and Felix Holt is the city of Naples; that in Romola is the Kingdom of Naples, which in the fifteenth century was one of the five great powers of Italy. At the beginning of Romola its ruler was the "Spanish-born old King Ferdinand", who was succeeded 1494 by his son Alfonso.
Source: Multiple (Romola, Daniel Deronda, Felix Holt, the Radical)

Title: Mediterranean (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Mediterranean (Real)^^The Mediterranean is a definite part of the scene in two of the novels. In Daniel Deronda Gwendolen Harleth and her husband, Grandcourt, go yachting on the Mediteranean, and Grandcourt is drowned in it while sailing a small boat near Genoa, and Gwendolen is rescued from drowning when she leaps over board after him. In Romola, Romola de' Bardi, sick at heart after her god-father's execution, sets herself adrift in a small fishing boat, hoping that she may never return ; instead she is carried to the plague-stricken village, where, in helping the sufferers, she wins back some peace and strength for herself.

Title: Milan (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Milan (Real)^^The Italian city where Lady Cheverel aids the poor musician Signor Sarti, and later rescues his orphan daughter, the little Caterina.

Title: Vienna (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Vienna (Real)^^In the Lifted Veil Vienna is one of the cities in which Latimer has an experience of clairvoyance. In Daniel Deronda it is one of the places where Mirah Cohen lived with her father, Lapidoth. The capital of Austria; at the time of Latimer's visit there the city had not yet assumed its modern aspect, and the city walls around the Innere Stadt were still standing.
Source: Multiple (The Lifted Veil, Daniel Deronda, Middlemarch)

Title: Prague (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Prague (Real)^^The European city, where, in Daniel Deronda, Mirah Cohen escapes from her father, Lapidoth. In the Lifted Veil, Latimer has a vision of this city in his first experience of clairvoyance; when he visits the city later he realizes the exactness of his vision. The ancient city of Prague, now the capital of Czechoslovakia, which at the time of Daniel Deronda belonged to Austria.

Title: Oxford (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: Oxford (Real)^^The English university where Arthur Donnithorne in Adam Bede, Rex Gascoigne and Mr. Lush in Daniel Deronda, Philip Debarry in Felix Holt, Latimer's brother, Alfred, in the Lifted Veil, and Mr. Stelling in Mill on the Floss have been educated.
Source: Multiple (The Lifted Veil, The Mill on the Floss, Felix Holt, the Radical, Daniel Deronda, Adam Bede)

Title: Bond, Mrs.
Subject: Character Name
Description: The churchwarden's wife, who takes charge of the Barton children during their mother's last illness.
Source: Multiple (The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton, Janet's Repentance)

Title: Shepperton
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Shepperton^^Parish where the Bartons live, and where Mr. Gilfil was vicar, many years earlier. "A flat ugly district this; depressing enough to look at even on the brightest days. The roads are black with coal dust, the brick houses dingy with smoke; and at that time-the time of handloom weavers-every other cottage had a loom at its window, where you might see a pale, sickly-looking man or woman preesing a narrow chest against a board, and doing a sort of tread-mill work with legs and arms. A troublesome district for a clergyman; at least to one . . . like Amos Barton." The original of Shepperton is Chilvers Coton, a suburb of Nuneaton.
Source: Multiple (The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton, Mr. Gilfil's Love Story, Janet's Repentance, Adam Bede)

Title: Pilgrim, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: A prosperous doctor in Milby. "Mr. Pilgrim, the doctor from the nearest market-town, who, though occasionally affecting aristocratic airs, and giving late dinners with enigmatic sidedishes and poisonous port, is never so comfortable as when he is relaxing his professional legs in one of those excellent farm-houses where the mice are sleek and the mistress sickly." "Pilgrim was tall, heavy, roughmannered, and spluttering . . . The doctor's estimate, even of a confiding patient, was apt to rise and fall with the entries in the day-book; and I have known Mr. Pilgrim discover the most unexpected virtues in a patient seized with a promising illness. . . . Doubtless this crescendo of benevolence was partly due to feelings not at all represented by the entries in the day-book; for in Mr. Pilgrim's heart, too, there was a latent store of tenderness and pity which flowed forth at the sight of suffering." The original of Mr. Pilgrim was a well-known doctor, Mr. Bucknill. (Manuscript in formation; also Olcott, George Eliot, p. 14; Parkinson, Scenes, p. 57.)
Source: Multiple (The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton, Mr. Gilfil's Love Story, Janet's Repentance)

Title: Rotherby
Subject: Fictional Place
Description: Rotherby^^Town near Shepperton and Milby. Original: Coventry.
Source: Multiple (The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton, Mr. Gilfil's Love Story, Janet's Repentance)

Title: Oldinport, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: The squire of Shepperton parish who helps Amos Barton when he is in need of money. The original of Mr. Oldinport was the Right Honourable Charle Newdigate Newdegate, Member of Parliament from Warwickshire 1843-84. (See Olcott, George Eliot, pp. 14, 24.)
Source: Multiple (The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton, Mr. Gilfil's Love Story)

Title: Oldinport Family
Subject: Character Name
Source: Multiple (The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton, Mr. Gilfil's Love Story)

Title: Bond, Mr.
Subject: Character Name
Description: Church warden at Shepperton.
Source: Multiple (The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton, Mr. Gilfil's Love Story)

Title: New York (Real)
Subject: Real Place
Description: New York (Real)^^The American city where, in Daniel Deronda, Mirah Cohen and her father, Lapidoth, live for some time, and where, in Middlemarch, Raffles goes with the money which Bulstrode has paid him to leave England.

Title: Naldo
Subject: Character Name
Description: A "painter of eclectic school", without power of application. He furnishes the contrast to Stradivarius in the poetic dialogue between the two.

Title: Giuseppe
Subject: Character Name
Description: A maker of violins, held by some people to be as good as Stradivarius.

Title: Stradivarius, Antonio (Hist.)
Subject: Historical Name
Description: The great violin maker who has the craftsman's delight in perfect work and defends his gospel of hard honest work against the jeers of Naldo the eclectic painter. "'Tis rare delight: I would not change my skill / To be the Emperor with bungling hands, / And lose my work, which comes as natural / As self at waking . . . / . . . 'Tis God gives skill, / But not without men's hands: / He could not make / Antonio Stradivari's violins / Without Antonio." The central idea of the poem, the delight of the work man in perfect work, George Eliot took from the character of her father, Robert Evans. Antonio Stradivari, or Stradivarius (1644-1737) was a famous Italian maker of violins.

Title: Michael
Subject: Character Name
Description: Angel "of pensive brow, snow-vest, and flaming sword".

Title: Zamael
Subject: Character Name
Description: Angel; "the terrible, the angel of fierce death, of agony that comes in battle and in pestilence."

Title: Gabriel
Subject: Character Name
Description: Angel, "the messenger of mildest death that draws the parting life."

Title: Jubal
Subject: Character Name
Description: Youngest son of Lamech who invents the lyre and discovers music. He wanders through the world for long years, seeking higher music and greater songs. After many years he returns, an old man, to find a newer generation celebrating him and his discovery of music in great festival. They believe, however, that he is dead, and when he proclaims himself the Jubal whom they are honouring he is jeered at and thrust out alone, to die. Dying, he is consoled by a vision of the greatness of his gift to man in the discovery of song.

Title: Jabal
Subject: Character Name
Description: Lamech's eldest son who "bore upon his face / The look of that calm river-god, the Nile, / Mildly secure in power that / needs not guile."

Title: Lamech
Subject: Character Name
Description: Jubal's father.

Title: "Black-eyed Monkey"
Subject: Item
Description: Sir Christopher Cheverel's name for Caterina.
